name: building operation, hostel | building operation, hostel | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/20825/documentation

This dataset represents the operation of a tourist accommodation facility located in Barranco, Lima, Peru. The case study hotel is classed as hostel. It was first opened in 2002 although the building where the hostel resides was constructed in early 1900s. Prior to becoming a hostel, the building was used as residence. The hostel has capacity of 56 beds and offers rooms of the following types (total number of rooms is given in brackets): double (2), triple (1), family (1) and shared use (8). The hostel has 1 floor which hosts a lobby, a restaurant and a bar. Laundry is outsourced and there is no parking available on site. The hostel occupies a total area of 700 m2 where the building itself occupies the plot of 550 m2. The average annual occupancy of the hostel is 54% which is equal to 11037 guest nights per year. The hostel's occupancy is somewhat lower than the country's average of 66%; (Source: Hotel News Now 2015. The state of Peru's tourism, hotels. Available from: http://www.hotelnewsnow.biz/Articles/27650/The-state-of-Perus-tourism-hotels Accessed 16 March 2018) which can in part be explained by the over-saturated market of hostels in Lima. Lima is a popular destination with backpackers and budget travellers who visit Lima as a place for a short stay prior to exploring the interior of Peru. This has triggered development of the hostel sector in Lima with subsequent enhanced competition. 

This dataset is modelled to represent the service of operating a hotel. It includes: energy and water consumption, furniture and in-room textiles (such as bed linen, bed mattrasses and curtains), electric and electronic equipment used in guest rooms and on hotel premises (including bulbs), cleaning and in-room consumables. The case study hotel uses services of an outsourced laundry. To account for its impacts, a separate laundry dataset has been added. This laundry dataset is based on the number of linen pieces sent to laundry by the hotel as reported in the hotel survey. The laundry dataset excludes trasnportation of linen to/from laundry due to data availability. Although the case study hotel has a restaurant on site, the inputs of food items have been excluded due to data availability. The energy and water consumption attibuted to restaurant operations have been included. Any waste generated in restaurant operations has been included. Activities include hotel operations and infrastructure based on 1 guest night stay and the lifeframe of the hotel building of 75 years. 


Activities end with guest departure from hotel premises. Due to data availability, the following processes have been excluded: room equipment (on-table lamp, door lock), bathroom equipment (showers, mirrors), food inputs in restaurant operations, transportation of linen to the outsourced laundry.
category: I:Accommodation and food service activities/55:Accommodation/551:Short term accommodation activities/5510:Short term accommodation activities

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The hostel is based in Lima, Peru.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Technology in use is considered current.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: In terms of operations, energy and water consumption are aggregate and represent the case study hostel as a whole, rather than its specific operational areas (e.g. guest rooms, restaurant and bar). The comments to respective processes explain this in detail.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Primary data from the hotel supplemented with literature-based calculations and estimates, where appropriate.

exchanges.description: This reference product represents operation of a tourist accommodation facility classed as a hostel.

flow.name: building operation, hostel
flow.category: I:Accommodation and food service activities/55:Accommodation/551:Short term accommodation activities/5510:Short term accommodation activities

exchanges.description: Estimated value. No primary data on the number of vacuum cleaners in use by the hotel but assumed that at least one vacuum cleaner is present for housekeeping purposes. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel/lifetime of the product) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hotel * hotel occupancy rate). Assumed average service life of a vacuum cleaner is 8 years. Source: Gallego-Schmid et al. 2016. Life cycle environmental impacts of vacuum cleaners and the effects of European regulation. Science of the Total Environment, 559, 192-203.

exchanges.description: Data from the hotel survey. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hotel * hotel occupancy rate). The amount also includes electricity requirements to produce cotton textile products from raw cotton. It is estimated that 2 MJ of electricity is required to produce 1 kg of cotton textile product. This accounts for 10% fabric loss in the cotton textile manufacturing process. Source: Baydar, G., Ciliz, N., and Mammadov, A., 2015. Life cycle assessment of cotton textile products in Turkey. Journal of Cleaner Production, 104(A), 213-223.

exchanges.description: Estimated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel/lifetime of the product) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hotel * hotel occupancy rate). Assumed average service life of all pieces of furniture is 15 years. This represents service life of an average piece of furniture. Source: European Commission 2013. BACKGROUND REPORT. Revision of Ecolabel and Green Public Procurement criteria for the product group Wooden Furniture. September 2013. Available from: http://susproc.jrc.ec.europa.eu/furniture/docs/Background_report_Furniture_September_2013.pdf Accessed 19 March 2018. This exchange represents the following: Bed single (unit) Assumed to have a weight of 21 kg, no headboard, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Bed king/queen (unit) King bed is assumed to have a weight of 30 kg, no headboard, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Bunk bed (unit) Bunk bed is assumed to have a weight of 50 kg, no headboard, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Bedside unit / table (unit) Bedside unit is assumed to have a weight of 14 kg, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Sofas (unit) Sofa is assumed to have a weight of 37 kg, two seater, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Tables/Desks (unit) Table is assumed to have a weight of 23 kg, medium, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Chairs (unit) Chair is assumed to have a weight of 7 kg, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. From the dataset for "cleaning consumables production" GLO 2011-2013, on average cleaning products contain 86% of water. Based on the literature source Golsteijn (2015) the dataset used to represent the water flow is "water, completely softened, at plant", version 2 dataset which corresponds to ecoinvent version 3 dataset "water, completely softened, from decarbonised waterm at user". The amount of water needed is therefore calculated based on the vale of 86% calculated based on Golsteijn (2015) and the amount of cleaning consumable which are expressed as 100% active substance.

Laura Golsteijn, 2015, A compilation of life cycle studies for six household detergent product categories in Europe: the basis for product-specific A.I.S.E. Charter Advanced Sustainability Profiles

exchanges.description: Calculated value from the total number of linen units used by the hotel. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel/lifetime of the product) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hotel * hotel occupancy rate). It is assumed that, on average, 4 linen units make 1 kg in weight. Source: Filimonau et al. 2011. Reviewing the carbon footprint analysis of hotels: Life Cycle Energy Analysis (LCEA) as a holistic method for carbon impact appraisal of tourist accommodation. Journal of Cleaner Production, 19, 1917-1930. Assumed average service life is 0.25 years. Source: TRSA 2015. Hospitality Textile Life, Loss and Replacement. Available from: http://www.laundrycompliance.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/trsa-hospitality-hotel-linen-loss.pdf Accessed 16 March 2018. The amount accounts for 10% fabric loss in the cotton textile manufacturing process. Source: Baydar, G., Ciliz, N., and Mammadov, A., 2015. Life cycle assessment of cotton textile products in Turkey. Journal of Cleaner Production, 104(A), 213-223.

The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hotel * hotel occupancy rate). Conversion from from meters to kg has been made assuming a roll of 25 meters weights 250 g, so 1 kg of tissue paper is equal to 100 meters. Source:  Sainsburys 2018. Andrex Toilet Paper. Available from: https://www.sainsburys.co.uk/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/gb/groceries/andrex-toilet-tissue--classic-white-16x241-sheets?langId=44&storeId=10151&krypto=6KE3AoChB8jlwzzYGlgparsN%2BBruZBOjUaSVm%2BCnwAT0LLJPLAalDm9DhCtUDzK5uFGmUkJJ%2FMIaDVx%2BGRGKIHdBUxaNbCTzmIQiBcpr497qZYrRt4Kvvy%2BLLO40d8j3%2BY4eQ%2Fk%2BK4BXsq0FOjWLrDLelOp5CVxrDysmNwGM26k%3D&ddkey=https%3Agb%2Fgroceries%2Fandrex-toilet-tissue--classic-white-16x241-sheets Accessed 16 January 2018. In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to wastewater.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hotel * hotel occupancy rate). Combined of all instances of use across the hotel operations. Represents the following cleaning luquids: window cleaner, bleach, washing up liquid, insect killer, pine disinfector, odour eliminator. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to wastewater. As the product "cleaning consumables" is expressed as 100% active substance, the amount of cleaning consumables is multiplied by the average concentration of active substance. According to Golsteijn (2015) the average water content of cleaning consumables is 86.4%, the necessary water input is accounted for with the flow "water, compeltely softened, from decarbonised water, at user". For more information on how the cleaning consumables dataset was created please refer to the relevant dataset in ecoinvent.

2015, Laura Golsteijn, A compilation of life cycle studies for six household detergent product categories in Europe: the basis for product-specific A.I.S.E. Charter Advanced Sustainability Profiles

Assumed average service life of a cookstove is 15 years. Source: Jungbluth 1997. Life-Cycle-Assessment for Stoves and Ovens. UNS Working Paper No. 16, August 1997.
